content.text: To establish a fair, consistent, and transparent assessment system that measures student progress, informs teaching and learning, and provides meaningful feedback to students and parents. Our philosophy is that assessment is primarily a tool for learning, not just of learning.
A balanced assessment approach is used to build a comprehensive picture of student achievement.

content.title: Assessment Framework
rows: To identify prior knowledge and misconceptions before a unit.
Pre-unit quiz, K-W-L chart, entry ticket.
To monitor learning and provide ongoing feedback during a unit.
Quizzes, exit tickets, teacher observation, peer feedback, mini-whiteboards.
To evaluate learning at the end of a unit or term.
End-of-unit tests, final projects, essays, presentations, Cambridge exams.

content.text: Grading scales are aligned with the Cambridge pathway and provide clear benchmarks of performance.

content.title: Grade Level Scales
rows: Provides a clear numerical measure of performance in preparation for IGCSE.
Final grades are A*-G. Internal reports use percentages for detailed feedback.
Final grades are A-E. Internal reports use percentages.

content.text: Feedback is designed to be timely, specific, and actionable, helping students understand their strengths and how to improve.

content.title: Core Principles (WWW/EBI)
items: What Went Well (WWW): Teachers identify and praise specific strengths in student work.
Even Better If (EBI): Teachers provide a clear, actionable target for improvement.
Student Response: Students are given dedicated time (e.g., 'Purple Pen of Progress') to read, reflect on, and respond to teacher feedback.

content.label: Turnaround Time
content.text: Major assignments should be marked and returned to students within two school weeks.

content.title: Key Assessments
items: EASE (Eduversal Achievement of Standardized Echievement): Internal standardized tests administered 2-4 times a year to track progress and inform instruction.
Cambridge Checkpoint: Diagnostic tests at the end of Primary (Grade 6) and Lower Secondary (Grade 8) to benchmark against international standards.
Cambridge IGCSE & A Level Exams: External, high-stakes examinations leading to globally recognized qualifications.
ANBK (Asesmen Nasional Berbasis Komputer): National assessment for Indonesian schools, measuring literacy, numeracy, and character.
Report Cards: Issued at the end of each term/semester, providing grades, effort marks, and teacher comments.
Parent-Teacher Conferences (PTCs): Held at least twice a year to discuss student progress in detail.
EduNav Parent Portal: Provides real-time access to grades, attendance, and school announcements.

content.purpose: To ensure all student work is authentic and to educate students on ethical academic practices.
content.scope: Applies to all assignments, projects, and examinations.
examples: Plagiarism: Submitting another's work as one's own without citation.
Collusion: Working with others on an individual assignment without permission.
Cheating: Using unauthorized aids during an examination.

steps.title: Education
steps.desc: Teachers explicitly teach citation, paraphrasing, and ethical research skills.

steps.title: Detection
steps.desc: Use of plagiarism detection software (e.g., Turnitin) for major assignments.

steps.title: Consequences
steps.desc: A tiered response, from re-doing the assignment with a penalty to suspension for repeated or severe offenses.

content.text: To ensure that grading is consistent and reliable across different teachers and classes.

items: Internal Moderation: Before finalizing grades for major assessments, teachers of the same subject meet to review and standardize a sample of student work against the rubric.
External Moderation: For Cambridge IGCSE and A Level coursework, samples are sent to Cambridge for external moderation to ensure global standards are met.
